scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-289 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-289 is a star with 1.08 times the mass of the Sun, and 1 times its radius. It is located 2297.57 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 0.65 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

Kepler-289 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-289 system


Kepler-289 b

Kepler-289 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-289 b is 7.314 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-289 b is 2.150 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-289 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.


Kepler-289 c

Kepler-289 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-03, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.51 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-289 c is 133.560 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-289 c is 11.590 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-289 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


Kepler-289 d

Kepler-289 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory, in 2014-11, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.33 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-289 d is 4.134 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-289 d is 2.680 that of Earth. With a mass below 5 Earth masses, a density of 1.2, and a semi-major axis of 0.33 astronomical units, Kepler-289 d could, potentially, be an ocean world - a planet with no dry land.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-289, which contains 3 exoplanets and was discovered by the Kepler.
name: Kepler-289 - System With 3 Exolanets
